Stream: theory: mathematics

Topic: Big Witt ring

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 17:09):

I'm trying to understand the "big Witt ring" of a commutative ring; there are various perspectives on it.

1) One slick abstract perspective is that the forgetful functor from [[lambda-rings]] to commutative rings has both the expected left adjoint but also a right adjoint

W:CommRing→λRingW : \mathsf{CommRing} \to \lambda\mathsf{Ring} W:CommRing→λRing

and W(R)W(R)W(R) is the big Witt ring. This perspective is helpful in proportion to how well you understand lambda-rings. There are several perspectives on lambda-rings, each of which should give a different outlook on the big Witt ring. My favorite is that when you decategorify a 2-rig by taking its Grothendieck group, you get not only a ring but a lambda-ring. But there is another important perspective based on number theory, where a lambda-ring is a commutative ring equipped with commuting [[Frobenius lifts]], one for each prime ppp.

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 17:14):

2) The underlying set of W(R)W(R)W(R) is

CommRing(Λ,R) \mathsf{CommRing}(\Lambda, R) CommRing(Λ,R)

where Λ\LambdaΛ is the underlying ring of the free lambda-ring on one generator. I will explain why later.

Λ\LambdaΛ is a biring, i.e. a ring object in CommRingop\mathsf{CommRing}^{\text{op}}CommRingop, and the multiplication in W(R)W(R)W(R) comes from the comultiplication in Λ\LambdaΛ.

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 17:23):

3) Since one can show the underlying commutative ring of the free lambda-ring on one generator is

Λ=Z[λ1,λ2,… ]] \Lambda = \mathbb{Z}[\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \dots ]]Λ=Z[λ1​,λ2​,…]]

we have an isomorphism of sets

W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]⊂R[[t]] W(R) \cong 1 + t R[[t]] \subset R[[t]]W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]⊂R[[t]]

where

f∈Z[λ1,λ2,… ]] f \in \mathbb{Z}[\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \dots ]]f∈Z[λ1​,λ2​,…]]

is mapped to

1+∑n=1∞f(λi)tn 1 + \sum_{n = 1}^\infty f(\lambda_i) t^n 1+∑n=1∞​f(λi​)tn

Then the challenge is to describe the addition and multiplication on W(R)W(R)W(R) in these terms. People often do this with explicit formulas, which I tend to find cryptic. The addition in W(R)W(R)W(R) corresponds to the multiplication in 1+R[[t]]1 + R[[t]]1+R[[t]], which is why we use this description. The multiplication in W(R)W(R)W(R) is more tricky. For any a∈Ra \in Ra∈R we get an element of W(R)W(R)W(R) called (1−at)−1(1 - a t)^{-1}(1−at)−1, defined by

(1−at)−1=1+at+a2t2+⋯ (1 - a t)^{-1} = 1 + a t + a^2 t^2 + \cdots (1−at)−1=1+at+a2t2+⋯

and the multiplication ⋅W\cdot_W⋅W​ on W(R)W(R)W(R) turns out to be determined once we know

(1−at)−1⋅W(1−bt)−1=(1−abt)−1 (1 - a t)^{-1} \cdot_W (1 - b t)^{-1} = (1 - a b t)^{-1} (1−at)−1⋅W​(1−bt)−1=(1−abt)−1

This formula turns out to be very useful but I don't have a good understanding of how it comes from 2).

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 17:31):

4) There's a ring isomorphism

W(R)≅R×R×R×⋯ W(R) \cong R \times R \times R \times \cdots W(R)≅R×R×R×⋯

where a∈W(R)a \in W(R)a∈W(R) is sent to (g1(a),g2(a),… )(g_1(a), g_2(a), \dots) (g1​(a),g2​(a),…), and

gi:W(R)→R g_i : W(R) \to R gi​:W(R)→R

sends a∈Ra \in Ra∈R to something called its ith ghost component. Here's an explicit formula for the ghost components that one often sees. Start by using the isomorphism

W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]W(R) \cong 1 + t R[[t]] W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]

from 3) to write a∈W(R)a \in W(R)a∈W(R) as a power series in ttt. Then write

tddtln⁡a=∑i=1giti \displaystyle{ t \frac{d}{d t} \ln a = \sum_{i = 1} g_i t^i } tdtd​lna=i=1∑​gi​ti

This is quite cryptic at first sight, but there has got to be some conceptual interpretation, probably involving [[Adams operations]].

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 17:44):

5) Back to conceptual interpretations, Cartier noticed that the big Witt ring W(R)W(R)W(R) can be seen as the ring of all formal curves starting at 111 in the multiplicative group of RRR... or something like that. This is explained here, where that ring of formal curves starting at 111 is called C(Gm,R)C(\mathbb{G}_m, R)C(Gm​,R).

This is probably just another way of thinking about 3), but it connects the big Witt ring to formal group laws, and in particular the "multiplicative formal group law", and I believe this should ultimately clarify the following trio of facts: a) the KKK-theory of any space is a λ\lambdaλ-ring, b) KKK-theory is a complex oriented cohomology theory, 3) such cohomology theories are classified by formal group laws, 4) KKK-theory corresponds to the multiplicative formal group law.

(Cartier generalized the big Witt ring to an arbitrary formal group law.)

John Baez (Oct 06 2024 at 19:19):

It should be possible to clearly see how all these facts follow from the definition 1), but I'm not there yet!

Here's how 1) implies 2). We use the fact that the forgetful functor

U:λRing→CommRingU : \lambda\mathsf{Ring} \to \mathsf{CommRing}U:λRing→CommRing

has not only a left adjoint

F:CommRing→λRingF: \mathsf{CommRing} \to \lambda\mathsf{Ring}F:CommRing→λRing

but also a right adjoint

W:CommRing→λRingW: \mathsf{CommRing} \to \lambda\mathsf{Ring}W:CommRing→λRing

Let's use this to compute the underlying set of W(R)W(R)W(R) for some commutative ring RRR.

The underlying set of any commutative ring AAA is CommRing(Z[x],A)\mathsf{CommRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], A)CommRing(Z[x],A) since Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] is the free commutative ring on one generator.

Thus the underlying set of (the underlying commutative ring of) W(R)W(R)W(R) is

CommRing(Z[x],U(W(R))\mathsf{CommRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], U(W(R)) CommRing(Z[x],U(W(R))

but since UUU has a left adjoint LLL this is

λRing(F(Z[x]),W(R)) \lambda\mathsf{Ring}(F(\mathbb{Z}[x]), W(R)) λRing(F(Z[x]),W(R))

and since WWW has a left adjoint UUU this is

Ring(U(F(Z[x])),R)\mathsf{Ring}(U(F(\mathbb{Z}[x])), R)Ring(U(F(Z[x])),R)

By general nonsense F(Z[x])F(\mathbb{Z}[x])F(Z[x]) is the free lambda-ring on one generator. The underlying commutative ring of this, U(F(Z[x]))U(F(\mathbb{Z}[x]))U(F(Z[x])), is denoted Λ\LambdaΛ. So, from this we get

The underlying set of W(R)W(R)W(R) is isomorphic to the set of ring homomorphisms from Λ\LambdaΛ to RRR.

It happens that Λ\LambdaΛ is the ring of [[symmetric functions]], but we didn't need this in the above argument. It also happens that the ring of symmetric functions is the polynomial ring on generators λi\lambda^iλi called [[elementary symmetric functions]]. This is called the fundamental theorem of symmetric functions. We used this to see why 2) implies 3).

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:18):

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Where did this come from original and why is it named after Witt? I've never heard of it, so I'm curious how it connects to other things and why you're interested in understanding it now ;)

Let me dig into the history....

Okay, it turns out Witt introduced a kind of "Witt vector" associated to an algebra over a field of characteristic ppp back in 1936, in his paper Zyklische Körper und Algebren der Characteristik ppp vom Grad pnp^npn. Struktur diskret bewerteter perfekter Körper mit vollkommenem Restklassenkörper der Charakteristik pnp^npn. No, that's not the whole paper - it's just the title.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:21):

Given a commutative ring and a prime ppp we can make up a "ppp-typical Witt ring" containing these Witt vectors. But then someone noticed you can combine all these ppp-typical Witt rings in a single "big Witt ring", and that's what I'm talking about.

People use these for various mysterious number-theoretic tasks, which I would like to understand someday.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:28):

But here's why I'm actually interested!

The big Witt ring is now best understood as the cofree lambda-ring on a commutative ring. Lambda-rings are important in representation theory, where they let us study things like exterior powers and symmetric powers of representations. But also, surprisingly, they're important in number theory, where they let us study things like "Frobenius lifts" - lifting the Frobenius endomorphism of a field to commutative algebras over that field.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:30):

For a long time I've been interested, just as a hobby, in understanding why people think the Riemann Hypothesis is connected to the "field with one element". So I was very interested when lambda-rings and the big Witt ring beame important in James Borger's approach to the field with one element:

  • James Borger, Lambda-rings and the field with one element.

His idea is that an algebra over the field with one element is a lambda-ring.

Digging into this, I've come to understand fairly well how lambda-rings arise from decategorifying concepts from representation theory. I've always liked representation theory, and @Joe Moeller and @Todd Trimble and I have showed that categories of representations tend to be 2-rigs, and the Grothendieck group of any 2-rig is a lambda-ring.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:32):

But I'm less comfortable with how lambda-rings are connected to number theory and Frobenius lifts. Mainly, it seems like a miracle that lambda-rings show up in two different contexts: representation theory in characteristic zero, and number theory in characteristic ppp!

They can't really be different; they must be deeply connected, so I want to understand this.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:36):

One way for me to start understanding this is to take the big Witt ring of a ring RRR, which doesn't seem to involve number theory or primes - it's just the cofree lambda-ring on RRR - and see how it's built from ppp-typical lambda rings, one for each prime.

John Baez (Oct 07 2024 at 17:38):

For years I've felt I don't have the intelligence to fully understand the big Witt ring - so I wished there were some sort of "half-Witt ring" to practice on. But it's gradually starting to make sense.

John Baez (Oct 08 2024 at 18:59):

Josselin Poiret said:

the explanation in the nlab was very useful to understand why lambda rings are interesting

Yes, thanks! It seems to have improved since I last read it, or maybe I just know more now. This is about what Borger calls the heterodox interpretation of a lambda-ring as a ring with a family of commuting Frobenius lifts, one for each prime.

John Baez (Oct 08 2024 at 19:22):

Equivalently it can be seen as a ring with with commuting [[p-derivations]] - a generalization of the concept of derivation. This allows us to develop a number-theoretic generalization of the concept of Taylor series, building on the known analogy between the ring of formal power series Z[[x]]\mathbb{Z}[[x]]Z[[x]] and the ring of p-adic integers, which gives a geometrical interpretation of localizing at a prime. If we go down this fascinating road, it's good to treat a lambda-ring as a [[Joyal delta-ring]].

John Baez (Oct 08 2024 at 19:25):

But I understand a lot more about what Borger calls the orthodox interpretation of lambda-rings, which is a ring equipped with λ\lambdaλ-operations. The idea here is that if we have a category with well-behaved "exterior power" operations, like a category of vector bundles or group representations, these will endow it's Grothendieck ring with λ\lambdaλ-operations making it into a lambda-ring.

John Baez (Oct 08 2024 at 22:23):

I find this to be a great intro to the 'heterodox' interpretation of lambda-rings and the big Witt ring:

  • Kiran Kedlaya, Notes on prismatic cohomology.

Ignore the scary title and read the nice review material!

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 05:01):

Todd and I were talking about how multiplication in the big Witt ring W(R)W(R)W(R) of a commutative ring RRR arises from comultiplication in the biring of symmetric functions Λ\LambdaΛ, via the formula

W(R)=CRing(Λ,R) W(R) = \mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, R)W(R)=CRing(Λ,R)

Recall that as a commutative ring,

Λ=Z[λ1,λ2,… ]\Lambda = \mathbb{Z}[\lambda^1, \lambda^2, \dots ]Λ=Z[λ1,λ2,…]

which we could conceivably write as

Λ=Z[λ1(x),λ2(x),… ]\Lambda = \mathbb{Z}[\lambda^1(x), \lambda^2(x), \dots ]Λ=Z[λ1(x),λ2(x),…]

to emphasizing Λ\LambdaΛ is the free λ\lambdaλ-ring on one generator xxx. In fact Todd uses such a notation for the free λ\lambdaλ-ring on two generators xxx and yyy, which is Λ⊗Λ\Lambda \otimes \LambdaΛ⊗Λ.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 05:06):

Since comulltiplication

μ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ \mu: \Lambda \to \Lambda \otimes \Lambda μ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ

is a ring homomorphism, it will be determined once we know what it does to each of the generators λi\lambda^iλi. I think Todd showed me how it works for λ1\lambda^1λ1 and I asked how it worked for λ2\lambda^2λ2, or something like that. Here was his reply - we've decided to talk about this here.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 05:07):

You asked what does the comultiplication

μ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ\mu: \Lambda \to \Lambda \otimes \Lambdaμ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ

applied to λ2\lambda^2λ2 look like. Short answer:

(μ(λ2))(x,y)=(λ1(x))2λ2(y)+λ2(x)(λ1(y))2−2λ2(x)λ2(y)(\mu(\lambda^2))(x, y) = (\lambda^1(x))^2 \lambda^2(y) + \lambda^2(x)(\lambda^1(y))^2 - 2\lambda^2(x)\lambda^2(y)(μ(λ2))(x,y)=(λ1(x))2λ2(y)+λ2(x)(λ1(y))2−2λ2(x)λ2(y)

where we think of Λ⊗Λ\Lambda \otimes \LambdaΛ⊗Λ as the free lambda-ring on two generators x,yx, yx,y. This can also be written more nicely as σ2(x)λ2(y)+λ2(x)σ2(y)\sigma^2(x) \lambda^2(y) + \lambda^2(x) \sigma^2(y)σ2(x)λ2(y)+λ2(x)σ2(y).

Longer answer: use the splitting principle, which guarantees that the 2-rig map kS‾→A⊠n\overline{k\mathsf{S}} \to \mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes n}kS→A⊠n, sending the generator xxx to a sum x1⊕…⊕xnx_1 \oplus \ldots \oplus x_nx1​⊕…⊕xn​ of nnn independent bosonic subline objects, is an extension when restricted to polynomial functors of degree ≤n\leq n≤n. Since λ2\lambda^2λ2 is degree 222, this means in effect that we can pretend the generator xxx of kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS is a sum x1+x2x_1 + x_2x1​+x2​ of two bosonic sublines. Then the 2-rig comultiplication kS‾→kS‾⊠kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}} \to \overline{k\mathsf{S}} \boxtimes \overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS→kS⊠kS, taking xxx to x⊠yx \boxtimes yx⊠y per our first paper, induces the map of lambda-rings Λ→Λ⊗Λ\Lambda \to \Lambda \otimes \LambdaΛ→Λ⊗Λ that takes x=x1+x2x = x_1 + x_2x=x1​+x2​ to x⊗y=(x1+x2)(y1+y2)=x1y1+x1y2+x2y1+x2y2x \otimes y = (x_1 + x_2)(y_1 + y_2) = x_1y_1 + x_1y_2 + x_2y_1 + x_2y_2x⊗y=(x1​+x2​)(y1​+y2​)=x1​y1​+x1​y2​+x2​y1​+x2​y2​. Since this lambda-ring map preserves the λ2\lambda^2λ2 operation, we calculate

μ(λ2x)=λ2(μx)=λ2(x1y1+x1y2+x2y1+x2y2)\mu(\lambda^2 x) = \lambda^2 (\mu x) = \lambda^2(x_1y_1 + x_1y_2 + x_2y_1 + x_2y_2)μ(λ2x)=λ2(μx)=λ2(x1​y1​+x1​y2​+x2​y1​+x2​y2​)

and use the exponential law for λ2\lambda^2λ2 plus vanishing of λ2(xiyj)\lambda^2(x_i y_j)λ2(xi​yj​) to write this out long-hand. Sparing some gory details, this gives the answer in the short identity.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:35):

I wonder how much of this needs to be explained further?

To my taste, the symbols λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi refer primarily to certain functors, and secondarily to symmetric functions; ultimately these two points of view are united via the all-powerful splitting principle. More precisely, the ring Λ\LambdaΛ is the Grothendieck group or ring based on isomorphism classes of Schur functors, which are essentially those endofunctors on the category of vector spaces (let's say over C\mathbb{C}C) that you can build up using ⊗\otimes⊗ (together with its symmetric monoidal structure), coproducts, and splitting of idempotents. For example, V↦V⊗VV \mapsto V \otimes VV↦V⊗V is a Schur functor. If σ:V⊗V→V⊗V\sigma: V \otimes V \to V \otimes Vσ:V⊗V→V⊗V denotes the symmetry that swaps tensor factors, then the endomorphisms

1+σ2:V⊗V→V⊗V,1−σ2:V⊗V→V⊗V\frac{1 + \sigma}{2}: V \otimes V \to V \otimes V, \qquad \frac{1-\sigma}{2}: V \otimes V \to V \otimes V21+σ​:V⊗V→V⊗V,21−σ​:V⊗V→V⊗V

are idempotent maps, and we can split these idempotents to obtain the symmetric square S2(V)S^2(V)S2(V) and exterior square Λ2(V)\Lambda^2(V)Λ2(V). Likewise, the symmetric power and exterior power functors, V↦Sn(V)V \mapsto S^n(V)V↦Sn(V) and V↦Λn(V)V \mapsto \Lambda^n(V)V↦Λn(V), are Schur functors. Tensor products and coproducts of Schur functors are again Schur functors, and Schur functors are closed under composition.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:35):

The symbols λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi can be read as the isomorphism classes [Λi][\Lambda^i][Λi] and [Si][S^i][Si], regarded as elements of the ring Λ\LambdaΛ (whose addition is induced from taking coproducts, and whose multiplication is induced from taking tensor products). It turns out -- and this is by no means trivial -- that as a ring, Λ\LambdaΛ is isomorphic to the polynomial algebra Z[λ1,λ2,…]\mathbb{Z}[\lambda^1, \lambda^2, \ldots]Z[λ1,λ2,…]. It is also the polynomial algebra Z[σ1,σ2,…]\mathbb{Z}[\sigma^1, \sigma^2, \ldots]Z[σ1,σ2,…]: both sets {λi}\{\lambda^i\}{λi} and {σi}\{\sigma^i\}{σi} serve as polynomial bases. There are other famous bases as well, which I won't mention right now, but you can read about them in famous texts such as Representation Theory by Fulton and Harris, and Symmetric Functions and Hall Polynomials by MacDonald.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:36):

But there is so much more to Λ\LambdaΛ! People go gaga over the richness of its structure and its interplay with the rest of mathematics. I'll try to indicate some main features of this structure by first pointing to similar features of a far simpler structure, namely the polynomial algebra Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x], which represents the forgetful functor

U:CRing→SetU: \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{Set}U:CRing→Set

in the sense of a natural isomorphism U≅CRing(Z[x],−)U \cong \mathsf{CRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], -)U≅CRing(Z[x],−). Now, we can remind the forgetful functor of its (tautological) ring object structure, by pointing at natural transformations a:U×U→Ua: U \times U \to Ua:U×U→U (whose components are the addition functions U(R)×U(R)→U(R)U(R) \times U(R) \to U(R)U(R)×U(R)→U(R)) and m:U×U→Um: U \times U \to Um:U×U→U (multiplication). At the level of the representing object Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x], these transformations are induced by ring homomorphisms

α:Z→Z[x]⊗Z[x],μ:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]\alpha: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x], \qquad \mu: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]α:Z→Z[x]⊗Z[x],μ:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]

Here we should pause to note that A⊗BA \otimes BA⊗B is the coproduct of commutative rings A,BA, BA,B, which means, by the universal property of coproducts, that CRing(A⊗B,−)≅CRing(A,−)×CRing(B,−)\mathsf{CRing}(A \otimes B, -) \cong \mathsf{CRing}(A, -) \times \mathsf{CRing}(B, -)CRing(A⊗B,−)≅CRing(A,−)×CRing(B,−). Thus Z[x]⊗Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x]⊗Z[x] is the representing object of U×UU \times UU×U.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:36):

In any category with coproducts, we can define a notion of co-ring object, dual to the notion of a ring object in a category with products. So what we can say is that according to the above, Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] is a co-ring object in the category of rings. We call it a biring. I'll leave it as a semi-advanced exercise in applying the Yoneda lemma to figure out explicit formulas for the co-ring structure on Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] that we are talking about here.

Stepping back a little: any time a representable functor CRing(A,−):CRing→Set\mathsf{CRing}(A, -): \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{Set}CRing(A,−):CRing→Set has ring object structure -- or in other words lifts up through the forgetful functor U:CRing→SetU: \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{Set}U:CRing→Set to give an endofunctor G:CRing→CRingG: \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{CRing}G:CRing→CRing, the representing object AAA becomes a biring. It can be shown that such lifts of representable functors are necessarily limit-preserving, or better yet they are right adjoints. Thus right adjoint endofunctors on CRing\mathsf{CRing}CRing are equivalent to biring structures. The case of the biring Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] corresponds to the identity endofunctor on CRing\mathsf{CRing}CRing (which of course is a right adjoint).

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:36):

But wait, there's more! In our example, Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] carries another binary operation Z[x]×Z[x]→Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x] \times \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x]×Z[x]→Z[x], namely polynomial composition (p,q)↦p∘q(p, q) \mapsto p \circ q(p,q)↦p∘q (replacing the xxx in p(x)p(x)p(x) by q(x)q(x)q(x)). If you'll allow me to abuse language and write the identity functor as

CRing(Z[x],−):CRing→CRing\mathsf{CRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], -): \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{CRing}CRing(Z[x],−):CRing→CRing

for the biring Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] sitting in the contravariant slot, then the polynomial composition Z[x]×Z[x]→Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x] \times \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x]×Z[x]→Z[x] can be read as contravariantly inducing a transformation in the other direction,

CRing(Z[x],−)→CRing(Z[x],CRing(Z[x],−))\mathsf{CRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], -) \to \mathsf{CRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], \mathsf{CRing}(\mathbb{Z}[x], -))CRing(Z[x],−)→CRing(Z[x],CRing(Z[x],−))

(these manipulations might seem a tad puzzling, and indeed it takes some fancy footwork to put it just right, but I'm going to skip over that -- you can read Schur Functors and Categorified Plethysm for details). I'll just say that the polynomial composition on Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] corresponds to the identity transformation Id→Id∘Id\mathrm{Id} \to \mathrm{Id} \circ \mathrm{Id}Id→Id∘Id that is the comultiplication for the tautological comonad structure on Id\mathrm{Id}Id.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:37):

More generally, if AAA is a biring, and if there is a comonad structure on the lifted endofunctor CRing(A,−):CRing→CRing\mathsf{CRing}(A, -): \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{CRing}CRing(A,−):CRing→CRing, then the comultiplication transfers over to an operation (a function) A×A→AA \times A \to AA×A→A that behaves similarly to polynomial composition. This operation is called plethysm, and a biring equipped with a plethysm operation is called a plethory. So in summary, giving a plethory is equivalent to giving a right adjoint comonad on CRing\mathsf{CRing}CRing; the plethory is the representing object for that comonad.

So now I can tell you that the main structural features of Λ\LambdaΛ is that it carries a plethory structure. A rather complicated plethory structure that is still very far away from being fully understood.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:37):

Where does that plethory structure come from? Well, John mentioned at the top of this thread that the forgetful functor UUU from the category of lambda-rings to the category of commutative rings has both a left adjoint FFF (expected for abstract nonsense reasons) and a right adjoint GGG (a much more specialized circumstance). So GGG and also UUU are right adjoints, hence the comonad G∘UG \circ UG∘U is also a right adjoint. The plethory Λ\LambdaΛ is the representing object for that right adjoint comonad.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:38):

This likely still sounds very mysterious, because for example, what are lambda-rings? Instead of saying directly what they are, I'll say in a different way where the comonad GUGUGU comes from. In our paper Schur Functors and Categorified Plethysm, we explain that it is the result of decategorifying a 2-comonad that is much easier (conceptually) to understand. Namely, what we do is categorify the story I was telling, about how Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] with its plethory structure represents the identity comonad on commutative rings. In this particular categorification, commutative rings are replaced by 2-rigs, which are symmetric monoidal Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect-enriched categories which have coproducts and idempotent splittings. The forgetful functor CRing→Set\mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{Set}CRing→Set is replaced by the forgetful (2-)functor 2Rig→Cat\textbf{2Rig} \to \mathsf{Cat}2Rig→Cat. This forgetful functor is representable, by a category (rather, 2-rig) of abstract Schur functors, so this category Schur\mathrm{Schur}Schur is the replacement of Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] at the categorified level, and it is a 2-birig that represents the identity functor on the 2-category of 2-rigs. It carries a 2-plethory structure, corresponding to the tautological 2-comonad structure on this identity functor.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:38):

The air up here on this categorified mountaintop is clean and clear; the view is simple and beautiful. But then we descend, from Schur\mathrm{Schur}Schur down to its set of isomorphism classes, or really I mean its Grothendieck ring Λ\LambdaΛ. That descent process is called 'decategorification'. And it's a little tricky. It took us months of study to make sure of our footing and the right path down to the valley. After all, we start with the "easiest" 2-comonad in the world, the identity functor on 2-rigs, and somehow this decategorifies down to an extremely non-trivial comonad on commutative rings, namely this right adjoint comonad GUGUGU I mentioned. Then we can (and do) define lambda-rings to be the coalgebras of this comonad.

Okay, I've just given a thumbnail sketch of our first paper.

Todd Trimble (Oct 12 2024 at 16:38):

To return to the topic, though: John quoted my reply to a question he asked about a specific calculation, about the biring Λ\LambdaΛ. As I said, Λ\LambdaΛ, even just as a biring let alone a plethory, is a pretty complicated beast, and I believe not completely grasped in terms of giving explicit formulas for the comultiplication (co-addition is rather easier to deal with). But some small calculations you can do by hand, and I was describing to him how to go about calculating what the comultiplication μ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ\mu: \Lambda \to \Lambda \otimes \Lambdaμ:Λ→Λ⊗Λ does to the element λ2\lambda^2λ2, by exploiting the subject of our second paper, the splitting principle [set in the context of 2-rigs].

All this is related to the second and third posts at the top of this thread, where John is again in search of ways to wrap one's head around the comultiplication, and he was quoting some stuff he saw in a paper by Niranjan Ramachandran which gives some hints. I can come around to discussing that as well, but in order for others to be able to follow along, I thought it would help to give some background, hence this string of ear-bending comments.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 17:55):

I just noticed a small notational point that might puzzle and perturb novices:

Todd Trimble said:

To my taste, the symbols λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi refer primarily to certain functors, and secondarily to symmetric functions; ultimately these two points of view are united via the all-powerful splitting principle. [...] If σ:V⊗V→V⊗V\sigma: V \otimes V \to V \otimes Vσ:V⊗V→V⊗V denotes the symmetry that swaps tensor factors, then the endomorphisms

1+σ2:V⊗V→V⊗V,1−σ2:V⊗V→V⊗V\frac{1 + \sigma}{2}: V \otimes V \to V \otimes V, \qquad \frac{1-\sigma}{2}: V \otimes V \to V \otimes V21+σ​:V⊗V→V⊗V,21−σ​:V⊗V→V⊗V

are idempotent maps, and we can split these idempotents to obtain the symmetric square Σ2(V)\Sigma^2(V)Σ2(V) and exterior square Λ2(V)\Lambda^2(V)Λ2(V). Likewise, the symmetric power and exterior power functors, V↦Sn(V)V \mapsto S^n(V)V↦Sn(V) and V↦Λn(V)V \mapsto \Lambda^n(V)V↦Λn(V) are Schur functors.

This point is that the symmetric functions σi\sigma^iσi are not powers of the "switch" map σ:V⊗V→V⊗V\sigma: V \otimes V \to V \otimes Vσ:V⊗V→V⊗V - instead there is a map sending Schur functors to symmetric functions, and the σi\sigma^iσi are the symmetric functions corresponding to the "ith symmetrized tensor power" functors V↦Si(V)V \mapsto S^i(V)V↦Si(V).

In the study of the symmetric group, people like lots of things named SSS, or S\mathsf{S}S, or Σ\SigmaΣ, or σ\sigmaσ, and sometimes we get carried away and the notations conflict!

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:16):

For other people listening in, let me try to give a conceptual explanation of these polynomials based on algebraic topology. Todd already knows this, at least implicitly, but I feel like saying it.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:19):

The operations of direct sum and tensor product can be applied to matrices, and in particular to unitary matrices, so if U(n)U(n)U(n) is the group of n ×n\times n×n unitary matrices then we get Lie group homomorphisms

⊕:U(m)×U(n)→U(m+n) \oplus: U(m) \times U(n) \to U(m + n) ⊕:U(m)×U(n)→U(m+n)

⊗:U(m)×U(n)→U(m×n) \otimes: U(m) \times U(n) \to U(m \times n)⊗:U(m)×U(n)→U(m×n)

We can work with all m,nm,nm,n simultaneously if we use the obvious inclusions

U(n)→U(n+1) U(n) \to U(n+1)U(n)→U(n+1)

to define the colimit of topological (or even 'smooth') groups

U=lim⁡⟶U(n) \displaystyle{ U = \lim_{\longrightarrow} U(n) } U=⟶lim​U(n)

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:22):

Then we get binary operations which are group homomorphisms

⊕:U×U→U \oplus : U \times U \to U ⊕:U×U→U

⊗:U×U→U \otimes: U\times U \to U⊗:U×U→U

in addition to the group operation, which is another binary operation. (By the way, I believe books on K-theory use an Eckmann-Hiltonesque argument to show that ⊕\oplus⊕ is homotopy equivalent to the group operation, and even better.)

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:24):

These maps induce maps on the classifying space for stable complex vector bundles, BUBUBU:

⊕:BU×BU→BU\oplus : BU \times BU \to BU⊕:BU×BU→BU

⊗:BU×BU→BU \otimes: BU \times BU \to BU⊗:BU×BU→BU

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:25):

and thus we get maps on K-theory going backward, which we can call coaddition and comultiplication:

α:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU) \alpha : K(BU) \to K(BU) \otimes K(BU) α:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)
μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)\mu: K(BU) \to K(BU) \otimes K(BU) μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:32):

Since KKK of any space also has a ring structure, these wind up making K(BU)K(BU)K(BU) into a 'biring'. But this biring is just our friend the free λ\lambdaλ-ring on on generator, which @Todd Trimble has been explaining. This is called Λ\LambdaΛ. As commutative rings we have

K(BU)≅Λ≅Z[λ1,λ2,… ]K(BU) \cong \Lambda \cong \mathbb{Z}[\lambda^1, \lambda^2, \dots ]K(BU)≅Λ≅Z[λ1,λ2,…]

Here λi\lambda^iλi, thought of as a symmetric function, is the ith elementary symmetric polynomial. But

K(BU)≅Heven(BU,Z)K(BU) \cong H^{\text{even}}(BU, \mathbb{Z})K(BU)≅Heven(BU,Z)

and thought of as an element of the integral cohomology of BUBUBU, λi\lambda^iλi is called the ith Chern class. It's a cohomology class of degree 2i.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:49):

So now let's think about what comultiplication

μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)\mu: K(BU) \to K(BU) \otimes K(BU) μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)

does to λi\lambda^iλi, in these terms!

I'll use the fact I hinted at: for a paracompact Hausdorff space XXX, the set of homotopy classes [X,BU][X,BU][X,BU] is isomorphic to the set of stable complex vector bundles over XXX: that is, equivalence classes of vector bundles over XXX, where we count two as equivalent if they become isomorphic after summing with the same complex vector bundle.

Using this and the definition of K-theory we get

K(X)≅[X,BU] K(X) \cong [X, BU]K(X)≅[X,BU]

After all K(X)K(X)K(X) is defined to be the set of stable complex vector bundles over XXX, made into a commutative ring using ⊕\oplus⊕ and ⊗\otimes⊗.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:57):

Thus, K(BU)≅[BU,BU]K(BU) \cong [BU, BU]K(BU)≅[BU,BU] is a somewhat self-referential entity: it's the commutative ring of stable vector bundles on BUBUBU. It's a ring because of the operations ⊕,⊗:BU×BU→BU\oplus, \otimes : BU \times BU \to BU⊕,⊗:BU×BU→BU acting on the covariant argument in [BU,BU][BU,BU][BU,BU], and a coring because of these operations acting on the contravariant argument in [BU,BU][BU,BU][BU,BU]

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 21:59):

I'm sort of meandering, but from all this we get yet another interpretation of the elements

λi∈Z[λ1,λ2,… ]≅Λ≅K(BU)\lambda^i \in \mathbb{Z}[\lambda^1, \lambda^2, \dots ] \cong \Lambda \cong K(BU)λi∈Z[λ1,λ2,…]≅Λ≅K(BU)

Namely, they must come from stable vector bundles on BUBUBU!

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:01):

I should describe these stable vector bundles, but I won't now. Instead, I just want to say what the

μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)≅K(BU×BU) \mu: K(BU) \to K(BU) \otimes K(BU) \cong K(BU \times BU)μ:K(BU)→K(BU)⊗K(BU)≅K(BU×BU)

does to each element λi\lambda^iλi.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:09):

It works like this: we can take any stable vector bundle on BUBUBU and pull it back along the tensor product map

⊗:BU×BU→BU\otimes : BU \times BU \to BU ⊗:BU×BU→BU

and get a stable vector bundle on BU×BUBU \times BUBU×BU. This induces a map

K(BU)→K(BU×BU)≅K(BU)⊗K(BU) K(BU) \to K(BU \times BU) \cong K(BU) \otimes K(BU)K(BU)→K(BU×BU)≅K(BU)⊗K(BU)

and this is just our friend the comultiplication μ\muμ.

So what does μ(λi)\mu(\lambda^i)μ(λi) mean? We start with the stable vector bundle λi\lambda^iλi on BUBUBU, and pull it back along ⊗:BU×BU→BU\otimes: BU \times BU \to BU⊗:BU×BU→BU. I believe every stable vector bundle on BU×BUBU \times BUBU×BU is an integral linear combination of tensor products of stable vector bundles λj⊠λk\lambda^j \boxtimes \lambda^kλj⊠λk, where ⊠\boxtimes⊠ is the 'external' tensor product of stable vector bundles: if you've got one on some space XXX and one on some space YYY, you can tensor them and get one on X×YX \times YX×Y.

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:13):

If so, we should be able to take μ(λi)\mu(\lambda^i)μ(λi), pull it back along ⊗\otimes⊗, and write it in terms of the λj⊠λk\lambda^j \boxtimes \lambda^kλj⊠λk. And I believe Todd's calculation is an example of this. He wrote

(μ(λ2))(x,y)=(λ1(x))2λ2(y)+λ2(x)(λ1(y))2−2λ2(x)λ2(y)(\mu(\lambda^2))(x, y) = (\lambda^1(x))^2 \lambda^2(y) + \lambda^2(x)(\lambda^1(y))^2 - 2\lambda^2(x)\lambda^2(y)(μ(λ2))(x,y)=(λ1(x))2λ2(y)+λ2(x)(λ1(y))2−2λ2(x)λ2(y)

but in my current notation I believe this means

μ(λ2)=(λ1)⊗2⊠λ2+λ2⊠(λ1)⊗2−2λ2⊠λ2\mu(\lambda^2) = (\lambda^1)^{\otimes 2} \boxtimes \lambda^2 + \lambda^2 \boxtimes (\lambda^1)^{\otimes 2} - 2\lambda^2 \boxtimes \lambda^2 μ(λ2)=(λ1)⊗2⊠λ2+λ2⊠(λ1)⊗2−2λ2⊠λ2

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:17):

The first term here is not manifestly a tensor product of stable vector bundles λj⊠λk\lambda^j \boxtimes \lambda^kλj⊠λk, but it actually is: it's

(λ1⊠λ2)⊗(λ1⊠1)( \lambda^1 \boxtimes \lambda^2) \otimes (\lambda^1 \boxtimes 1) (λ1⊠λ2)⊗(λ1⊠1)

where 111 is the trivial line bundle (the identity in the ring K(BU)K(BU)K(BU)).

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:19):

So, in short, the polynomial people call PiP_iPi​ answers this question

Given a stable vector bundle λi\lambda^iλi on BUBUBU, and pulling it back along ⊗:BU×BU→BU\otimes : BU \times BU \to BU⊗:BU×BU→BU, how can we express it in terms of the stable vector bundles λj⊠λk\lambda^j \boxtimes \lambda^kλj⊠λk?

John Baez (Oct 12 2024 at 22:19):

We could also frame this in terms of Chern classes.

All this 'fluffy' stuff doesn't help us compute the polynomials PiP_iPi​. And indeed, Todd already showed one way to do that. It simply says why we should care about these polynomials.

John Baez (Oct 16 2024 at 01:24):

@Todd Trimble had written to me some more about the big Witt ring, in which he starts analyzing some formulas from here:

  • Niranjan Ramachandran, Zeta functions, Grothendieck groups, and the Witt ring.

In particular, this paper discusses a formula for multiplication in the big Witt ring which I mentioned earlier:

John Baez said:

3) Since one can show the underlying commutative ring of the free lambda-ring on one generator is

Λ=Z[λ1,λ2,… ]] \Lambda = \mathbb{Z}[\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \dots ]]Λ=Z[λ1​,λ2​,…]]

we have an isomorphism of sets

W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]⊂R[[t]] W(R) \cong 1 + t R[[t]] \subset R[[t]]W(R)≅1+tR[[t]]⊂R[[t]]

where

f∈Z[λ1,λ2,… ]] f \in \mathbb{Z}[\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \dots ]]f∈Z[λ1​,λ2​,…]]

is mapped to

1+∑n=1∞f(λi)tn 1 + \sum_{n = 1}^\infty f(\lambda_i) t^n 1+∑n=1∞​f(λi​)tn

Then the challenge is to describe the addition and multiplication on W(R)W(R)W(R) in these terms. People often do this with explicit formulas, which I tend to find cryptic. The addition in W(R)W(R)W(R) corresponds to the multiplication in 1+R[[t]]1 + R[[t]]1+R[[t]], which is why we use this description. The multiplication in W(R)W(R)W(R) is more tricky. For any a∈Ra \in Ra∈R we get an element of W(R)W(R)W(R) called (1−at)−1(1 - a t)^{-1}(1−at)−1, defined by

(1−at)−1=1+at+a2t2+⋯ (1 - a t)^{-1} = 1 + a t + a^2 t^2 + \cdots (1−at)−1=1+at+a2t2+⋯

and the multiplication ⋅W\cdot_W⋅W​ on W(R)W(R)W(R) turns out to be determined once we know

(1−at)−1⋅W(1−bt)−1=(1−abt)−1 (1 - a t)^{-1} \cdot_W (1 - b t)^{-1} = (1 - a b t)^{-1} (1−at)−1⋅W​(1−bt)−1=(1−abt)−1

This formula turns out to be very useful but I don't have a good understanding of how it comes from 2).

John Baez (Oct 16 2024 at 01:26):

The first question is: why should we care about these elements (1−at)−1(1-at)^{-1}(1−at)−1? And the second is: what does the above formula for a product of them mean? And the third is: does it really determine the product on all of the big Witt ring W(R)W(R)W(R)?

Todd Trimble (Oct 16 2024 at 01:29):

Yes, sorry, I was going to say something about that! But let me collect my thoughts.

Todd Trimble (Oct 16 2024 at 01:32):

The paper of Ramachandran that John linked to mentioned that there are several reasonable choices for the (big) Witt ring multiplication. This has a lot to do with how there are various reasonable choices for a nice polynomial basis of Λ\LambdaΛ.

Todd Trimble (Oct 16 2024 at 01:36):

So going back to the message at the top of the thread: one conceptual way to define W(R)W(R)W(R) is that it is the hom-set CRing(Λ,R)\mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, R)CRing(Λ,R). Thanks to the rich plethory structure on Λ\LambdaΛ that I was sketching earlier, the hom-set acquires a commutative ring structure and even a lambda-ring structure, and indeed furnishes the right adjoint to the forgetful functor from lambda-rings to commutative rings, as John mentioned earlier.

Todd Trimble (Oct 16 2024 at 01:42):

Now it seems that a lot of sources introduce W(R)W(R)W(R) as consisting of formal power series with constant coefficient 111, i.e., elements in 1+tR[[t]]1 + tR[[t]]1+tR[[t]]. So there is an isomorphism CRing(Λ,R)→1+tR[[t]]\mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, R) \to 1 + tR[[t]]CRing(Λ,R)→1+tR[[t]], and John showed how this might go: using the polynomial basis λi\lambda^iλi, we can define this isomorphism as sending f:Λ→Rf: \Lambda \to Rf:Λ→R to 1+∑i≥1f(λi)ti1 + \sum_{i \geq 1} f(\lambda^i) t^i1+∑i≥1​f(λi)ti.

Another possibility is to use the polynomial basis σi\sigma^iσi, and define the isomorphism so as to send fff to 1+∑i≥1f(σi)ti1 + \sum_{i \geq 1} f(\sigma^i) t^i1+∑i≥1​f(σi)ti.

Todd Trimble (Oct 16 2024 at 01:48):

Each of these has its uses. But before tackling what any of this has to do with those formulas John mentioned, it might not be a bad exercise to look for a moment at how addition works in the Witt ring 1+tR[[t]]1 + tR[[t]]1+tR[[t]]. (No, it is not ordinary addition of power series!) It turns out that the same formula will work whether you use the λi\lambda^iλi basis or the σi\sigma^iσi basis, and it's based on the co-addition on Λ\LambdaΛ that was lightly alluded to. Maybe I'll pause a moment.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:53):

The plan is to see how co-addition works in the toy example of Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x], and then categorify that. In discussion above I said that the explicit formula for co-addition α:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]\alpha: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]α:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x] can be derived as a "semi-advanced exercise" in using the Yoneda lemma, so I'll start with that. I'll use the notation [A,B][A, B][A,B] to denote hom-sets (usually hom-sets that acquire extra structure). The Yoneda lemma is about representable functors. Here we have ϕ:[Z[x],−]≅U\phi: [\mathbb{Z}[x], -] \cong Uϕ:[Z[x],−]≅U where U:CRing→SetU: \mathsf{CRing} \to \mathsf{Set}U:CRing→Set is the forgetful functor; evaluated at a ring RRR, the isomorphism takes f:Z[x]→Rf: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to Rf:Z[x]→R to f(x)∈U(R)f(x) \in U(R)f(x)∈U(R). Similarly we have [Z[x]⊗Z[x],−]≅U×U[\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x], -] \cong U \times U[Z[x]⊗Z[x],−]≅U×U, instantiated by

[Z[x]⊗Z[x],−]⟶(π1,π2)[Z[x],−]×[Z[x],−]⟶ϕ×ϕU×U[\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x], -] \overset{(\pi_1, \pi_2)}{\longrightarrow} [\mathbb{Z}[x], -] \times [\mathbb{Z}[x], -] \overset{\phi \times \phi}{\longrightarrow} U \times U[Z[x]⊗Z[x],−]⟶(π1​,π2​)​[Z[x],−]×[Z[x],−]⟶ϕ×ϕ​U×U

where the first product projection π1\pi_1π1​ is induced by the first coproduct coprojection i1:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]:x↦x⊗1i_1: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]: x \mapsto x \otimes 1i1​:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]:x↦x⊗1, and π2\pi_2π2​ is induced by the second coproduct coprojection i2:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]:x↦1⊗xi_2: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]: x \mapsto 1 \otimes xi2​:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]:x↦1⊗x. Taking R=Z[x]⊗Z[x]R = \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]R=Z[x]⊗Z[x], chase the identity element 1Z[x]⊗Z[x]1_{\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]}1Z[x]⊗Z[x]​ through the sequence

[Z[x]⊗Z[x],R]⟶(π1,π2)[Z[x],R]×[Z[x],R]⟶ϕ×ϕU(R)×U(R)⟶+RU(R)⟶ϕ−1[Z[x],R],[\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x], R] \overset{(\pi_1, \pi_2)}{\longrightarrow} [\mathbb{Z}[x], R] \times [\mathbb{Z}[x], R] \overset{\phi \times \phi}{\longrightarrow} U(R) \times U(R) \overset{+_R}{\longrightarrow} U(R) \overset{\phi^{-1}}{\longrightarrow} [\mathbb{Z}[x], R],[Z[x]⊗Z[x],R]⟶(π1​,π2​)​[Z[x],R]×[Z[x],R]⟶ϕ×ϕ​U(R)×U(R)⟶+R​​U(R)⟶ϕ−1​[Z[x],R],

a la the proof of the Yoneda lemma. We get

1Z[x]⊗Z[x]↦(x↦i1x⊗1,x↦i21⊗x)↦(x⊗1,1⊗x)↦+x⊗1+1⊗x↦(x↦x⊗1+1⊗x).1_{\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]} \mapsto (x \overset{i_1}{\mapsto} x \otimes 1, x \overset{i_2}{\mapsto} 1 \otimes x) \mapsto (x \otimes 1, 1 \otimes x) \overset{+}{\mapsto} x \otimes 1 + 1 \otimes x \mapsto (x \mapsto x \otimes 1 + 1 \otimes x).1Z[x]⊗Z[x]​↦(x↦i1​​x⊗1,x↦i2​​1⊗x)↦(x⊗1,1⊗x)↦+​x⊗1+1⊗x↦(x↦x⊗1+1⊗x).

  \;

In other words, the co-addition α:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]\alpha: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]α:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x] is the unique ring map taking xxx to x⊗1+1⊗xx \otimes 1 + 1 \otimes xx⊗1+1⊗x.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:54):

The same type of calculation shows that the comultiplication μ:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x]\mu: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]μ:Z[x]→Z[x]⊗Z[x] is the unique map taking xxx to (x⊗1)⋅(1⊗x)=x⊗x(x \otimes 1) \cdot (1 \otimes x) = x \otimes x(x⊗1)⋅(1⊗x)=x⊗x.

(One could simply guess these formulas and check that they work, but I think it's nice to know how the Yoneda lemma removes any guesswork.)

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:55):

If one uses Z[x]⊗Z[x]≅Z[x,y]\mathbb{Z}[x] \otimes \mathbb{Z}[x] \cong \mathbb{Z}[x, y]Z[x]⊗Z[x]≅Z[x,y], in effect identifying x⊗1x \otimes 1x⊗1 with x∈Z[x,y]x \in \mathbb{Z}[x, y]x∈Z[x,y] and 1⊗x1 \otimes x1⊗x with y∈Z[x,y]y \in \mathbb{Z}[x, y]y∈Z[x,y], then the co-addition becomes simply the ring map Z[x]→Z[x,y]\mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x, y]Z[x]→Z[x,y] taking xxx to x+yx + yx+y, which makes everything look simple and obvious. The comultiplication takes xxx to xyxyxy.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:55):

Moving in the opposite direction, suppose given a (commutative, cocommutative) bi-ring BBB. The addition on [B,R]=CRing(B,R)[B, R] = \mathsf{CRing}(B, R)[B,R]=CRing(B,R) is retrieved from the co-addition α:B→B⊗B\alpha: B \to B \otimes Bα:B→B⊗B as a composite

[B,R]×[B,R]⟶∼[B⊗B,R]⟶[α,1R][B,R](1)[B, R] \times [B, R] \overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow} [B \otimes B, R] \overset{[\alpha, 1_R]}{\longrightarrow} [B, R] \qquad (1)[B,R]×[B,R]⟶∼​[B⊗B,R]⟶[α,1R​]​[B,R](1)

where the isomorphism obtains by the universal property of B⊗BB \otimes BB⊗B as a coproduct. To be explicit, this isomorphism takes a pair of homomorphisms (f:B→R,g:B→R)(f: B \to R, g: B \to R)(f:B→R,g:B→R) to the composite

B⊗B⟶f⊗gR⊗R⟶∇RB \otimes B \overset{f \otimes g}{\longrightarrow} R \otimes R \overset{\nabla}{\longrightarrow} RB⊗B⟶f⊗g​R⊗R⟶∇​R

where the codiagonal ∇\nabla∇ is precisely the multiplication m:R⊗R→Rm: R \otimes R \to Rm:R⊗R→R.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:56):

  \;

Hence the composite (1)(1)(1) takes a pair of morphisms (f,g)(f, g)(f,g) to the composite

B→αB⊗B→f⊗gR⊗R→mR(2)B \overset{\alpha}{\to} B \otimes B \overset{f \otimes g}{\to} R \otimes R \overset{m}{\to} R \qquad (2)B→αB⊗B→f⊗gR⊗R→mR(2)

and this defines f+gf + gf+g in the ring [B,R][B, R][B,R].

  \;

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:56):

Replacing the co-addition α\alphaα by comultiplication μ\muμ, the same construction as in (2)(2)(2) produces the product f⋅gf \cdot gf⋅g in [B,R][B, R][B,R].

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:56):

Now categorify all this. Replace Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x], the free commutative ring on one generator, with the free 2-rig on one generator, which is the (additive) Cauchy completion of the kkk-linearization of the free symmetric monoidal category S\mathsf{S}S on one generator. (To get anywhere interesting in categorifying commutative rings, you should add in some limits/colimits, and Cauchy completeness is a good place to start.) We write this as kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:57):

I think I mentioned before that this kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS is the representing 2-rig for the forgetful functor 2Rig→Cat\mathbf{2Rig} \to \mathsf{Cat}2Rig→Cat, and on those grounds alone, through abstract nonsense, one can copy over (or categorify) the development above for Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x], to derive a 2-birig structure on kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS, with a categorified co-addition given by the unique (up to isomorphism) 2-rig map

α:kS‾→kS(x,y)‾\alpha: \overline{k\mathsf{S}} \to \overline{k\mathsf{S}(x, y)}α:kS→kS(x,y)​

(where the codomain is the free 2-rig on two generators x,yx, yx,y) that sends the generator xxx of kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS to the formal coproduct x⊕yx \oplus yx⊕y in kS(x,y)‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}(x, y)}kS(x,y)​.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 18:58):

It is interesting to watch what α\alphaα does to objects like SnS^nSn and Λn\Lambda^nΛn in kS‾ \overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS. I'll start with SnS^nSn, the nthn^{th}nth symmetric power. For any 2-rig R\mathcal{R}R, there is a 2-rig R[N]\mathcal{R}[\mathbb{N}]R[N] of graded R\mathcal{R}R-objects (whose symmetric monoidal tensor is given by Day convolution, coming from N\mathbb{N}N), and one way we can view the symmetric power Sn(r)=r⊗n/SnS^n(r) = r^{\otimes n}/S_nSn(r)=r⊗n/Sn​ for an object rrr of R\mathcal{R}R, which I sometimes like to write as r⊗n/n!r^{\otimes n}/n!r⊗n/n!, is that it is the nthn^{th}nth homogeneous component of a symmetric algebra construction, which I will write as

exp⁡(r)=∑n≥0r⊗nn!=∑n≥0Sn(r).\exp(r) = \sum_{n \geq 0} \frac{r^{\otimes n}}{n!} = \sum_{n \geq 0} S^n(r).exp(r)=∑n≥0​n!r⊗n​=∑n≥0​Sn(r).

Here I'm thinking of the object rrr as sitting in grade 111 in R[N]\mathcal{R}[\mathbb{N}]R[N], so that Sn(r)S^n(r)Sn(r) sits in grade nnn. This exp⁡(r)\exp(r)exp(r) is the free commutative monoid on rrr, and the category of commutative monoid objects has ⊗\otimes⊗ as its coproduct. This free functor gives a (partially defined) left adjoint [I say "partial" because if for example r′r'r′ is in degree 000, then so would be exp⁡(r′)\exp(r')exp(r′), but maybe the 2-rig R\mathcal{R}R we started with doesn't have infinite coproducts like ∑n≥0Sn(r)\sum_{n \geq 0} S^n(r)∑n≥0​Sn(r) -- there's a better chance of success if the coproduct is spread across grades]. Since left adjoints preserve coproducts, we deduce an isomorphism

exp⁡(r⊕s)≅exp⁡(r)⊗exp⁡(s).\exp(r \oplus s) \cong \exp(r) \otimes \exp(s).exp(r⊕s)≅exp(r)⊗exp(s).

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 19:00):

  \;
Whereupon, focusing on one grade at a time, we further deduce

Sn(r⊕s)≅∑j+k=nSj(r)⊗Sk(s)S^n(r \oplus s) \cong \sum_{j + k = n} S^j(r) \otimes S^k(s)Sn(r⊕s)≅∑j+k=n​Sj(r)⊗Sk(s),

an identity which holds as a natural transformation between Schur functors of type R→R\mathcal{R} \to \mathcal{R}R→R. This holds in particular when R=kS(x,y)‾\mathcal{R} = \overline{k\mathsf{S}(x, y)}R=kS(x,y)​.

  \;

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 19:01):

Decategorifying this "identity" by taking isomorphism classes, i.e., by taking Grothendieck rings, this implies that the induced co-addition α:Λ→Λ⊗Λ\alpha: \Lambda \to \Lambda \otimes \Lambdaα:Λ→Λ⊗Λ satisfies

α(σn)=∑j+k=nσj(x)⊗σk(y)\alpha(\sigma^n) = \sum_{j + k = n} \sigma^j(x) \otimes \sigma^k(y)α(σn)=∑j+k=n​σj(x)⊗σk(y)

where the right side is visibly a convolution product.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 19:02):

Consider now the induced addition on [Λ,R][\Lambda, R][Λ,R] (RRR a commutative ring), sending a pair (f,g)(f, g)(f,g) of homomorphisms Λ→R\Lambda \to RΛ→R to the homomorphism

Λ⟶αΛ⊗Λ⟶f⊗gR⊗R⟶mR.\Lambda \overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow} \Lambda \otimes \Lambda \overset{f \otimes g}{ \longrightarrow} R \otimes R \overset{m}{\longrightarrow} R.Λ⟶α​Λ⊗Λ⟶f⊗g​R⊗R⟶m​R.

This composite takes σn\sigma^nσn to ∑j+k=nf(σj)g(σk)\sum_{j + k = n} f(\sigma^j) g(\sigma^k)∑j+k=n​f(σj)g(σk). In other words, Witt ring addition is defined by

(f+Wg)(σn)=∑j+k=nf(σj)g(σk)(f +_W g)(\sigma^n) = \sum_{j + k = n} f(\sigma^j) g(\sigma^k)(f+W​g)(σn)=∑j+k=n​f(σj)g(σk)

and if we set up an isomorphism [Λ,R]⟶∼1+tR[[t]][\Lambda, R] \overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow} 1 + tR[[t]][Λ,R]⟶∼​1+tR[[t]] by f↦∑n≥0f(σn)tnf \mapsto \sum_{n \geq 0} f(\sigma^n) t^nf↦∑n≥0​f(σn)tn, then the induced Witt ring addition on 1+tR[[t]]1 + tR[[t]]1+tR[[t]] is given by multiplying power series.

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 19:02):

It turns out the same is true if we use instead the isomorphism [Λ,R]⟶∼1+tR[[t]][\Lambda, R] \overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow} 1 + tR[[t]][Λ,R]⟶∼​1+tR[[t]] given by f↦∑n≥0f(λn)tnf \mapsto \sum_{n \geq 0} f(\lambda^n) t^nf↦∑n≥0​f(λn)tn. At the beginning of that story, we have the identity

Λn(r⊕s)≅∑j+k=nΛj(r)⊗Λk(s)\Lambda^n(r \oplus s) \cong \sum_{j + k = n} \Lambda^j(r) \otimes \Lambda^k(s)Λn(r⊕s)≅∑j+k=n​Λj(r)⊗Λk(s)

as a natural transformation between Schur functors on any 2-rig R\mathcal{R}R. To see this, we replace the 2-rig R[N]\mathcal{R}[\mathbb{N}]R[N] of graded objects, with its "vanilla" symmetry σ(u⊗v)=v⊗u\sigma(u \otimes v) = v \otimes uσ(u⊗v)=v⊗u for objects uuu in grade ppp and vvv in grade qqq, with the more sophisticated symmetry that introduces a sign factor, σ(u⊗v)=(−1)pqv⊗u\sigma(u \otimes v) = (-1)^{pq} v \otimes uσ(u⊗v)=(−1)pqv⊗u. Otherwise, the entire story (symmetric algebra construction as free commutative monoid, etc.) remains the same, mutatis mutandis, hence we get this "exponential identity". Therefore, Witt addition on formal power series is again multiplication, even if we opt for this other identification with 1+tR[[t]]1 + tR[[t]]1+tR[[t]].

Todd Trimble (Oct 17 2024 at 19:08):

Now that I've fully explained how addition on the big Witt ring works, I can turn my attention to how multiplication works. Multiplication of f,g:Λ→Rf, g: \Lambda \to Rf,g:Λ→R is defined by the composite

Λ⟶μΛ⊗Λ⟶f⊗gR⊗R⟶mR\Lambda \overset{\mu}{\longrightarrow} \Lambda \otimes \Lambda \overset{f \otimes g}{\longrightarrow} R \otimes R \overset{m}{\longrightarrow} RΛ⟶μ​Λ⊗Λ⟶f⊗g​R⊗R⟶m​R

where this time we have to figure out how comultiplication μ\muμ on Λ\LambdaΛ works. It is, of course, gotten by decategorifying (taking isomorphism classes) the unique (up to isomorphism) 2-rig map

kS‾→kS(x,y)‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}} \to \overline{k\mathsf{S}(x, y)}kS→kS(x,y)​

that takes the generator xxx to the formal tensor product x⊗yx \otimes yx⊗y.

Working this out in detail will involve the "splitting principle" for 2-rigs, which John will be discussing at the upcoming Octoberfest meeting, but perhaps I'll pause to take a break from this longish series of comments.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:46):

I'm going to push on with this series of posts; the next topic will be this splitting principle that I keep banging on about.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:47):

For us, the splitting principle is the idea that to establish isomorphisms between Schur functors, it is permissible to pretend that they can be decomposed as coproducts of "line objects". It is analogous to the splitting principle in K-theory, where equations are verified by acting as if vector bundles split as coproducts of line bundles.

This sounds a little flaky perhaps, so I'll put it more precisely in a moment, but first I want to say that the situation reminds me of how those Italian mathematicians from the late Renaissance who developed the cubic formula -- Cardano, Tartaglia, etc. -- made the bold move to act as if i=−1i = \sqrt{-1}i=−1​ were a thing. Even when all the roots of the cubic polynomial were real, they were arrived at by making use of imaginary elements. (True, they were fairly uncomfortable with the situation, and it took a few centuries before mathematicians felt generally at home with splitting extensions of fields.) The analogy is apt: the coefficients of a polynomial are symmetric functions of their roots, and the roots are analogous to the line objects we are about to discuss. Don't believe the analogy? That's okay. Humor me anyway by considering a linear transformation T:V→VT: V \to VT:V→V on a vector space. By passing to an extension of the scalar field if need be, i.e., adjoining roots, we can split VVV into a coproduct of eigenspaces (which generically are lines), by splitting the characteristic polynomial into linear factors.

(At the risk of too much self-indulgence: this also reminds me of splitting light into a spectrum, where the energy levels of photons are given by eigenvalues of a suitable operator.)

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:47):

Okay, now let me state the splitting principle more precisely. For the purposes of this thread, define a line object in a 2-rig R\mathcal{R}R to be a (nonzero) object rrr satisfying Λ2(r)≅0\Lambda^2(r) \cong 0Λ2(r)≅0. (In our paper, we say instead "bosonic subline object".) Another way of saying it is that the canonical quotient r⊗r→S2(r)r \otimes r \to S^2(r)r⊗r→S2(r) is an isomorphism, or equivalently that the symmetry σ:r⊗r→r⊗r\sigma: r \otimes r \to r \otimes rσ:r⊗r→r⊗r that transposes factors equals the identity. Or equivalently still, that the tautological action of SnS_nSn​ on r⊗nr^{\otimes n}r⊗n is trivial for all nnn. Finally, this last condition is equivalent to saying that for the symmetric powers SnS^nSn, we have Sn(r)≅r⊗nS^n(r) \cong r^{\otimes n}Sn(r)≅r⊗n for all nnn.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:48):

Just as kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS with its generator xxx is initial among 2-rigs equipped with an object, so kN‾\overline{k\mathbb{N}}kN (the linear Cauchy completion of the linearized discrete symmetric monoidal category N\mathbb{N}N) is initial among 2-rigs equipped with a line object. Here kN‾\overline{k\mathbb{N}}kN is equivalent to the category of N\mathbb{N}N-graded vector spaces of finite total dimension, which we in our paper denote as A\mathsf{A}A, and the line object in this universal case is a 1-dimensional vector space concentrated in grade 111. Likewise, the walking 2-rig on nnn line objects L1,…,LnL_1, \ldots, L_nL1​,…,Ln​, denoted as A⊠n\mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes n}A⊠n is equivalent to the category of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn-graded vector spaces of finite total dimension.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:48):

Assume the ground field kkk is of characteristic zero. Suppose given Schur objects F,G:S→VectF, G: \mathsf{S} \to \mathsf{Vect}F,G:S→Vect, also known as polynomial functors, say of degree nnn or less; the latter means they are valued in finite-dimensional vector spaces, and that their restrictions to the symmetric groups SmS_mSm​ are zero for m>nm > nm>n. Thus FFF is given by (let's say right) linear representations F[j]F[j]F[j] of SjS_jSj​ for j=0,…,nj = 0, \ldots, nj=0,…,n. The polynomial or Schur functor itself takes a finite-dimensional vector space VVV to F~(V):=∑j=0nF[j]⊗SjV⊗j\tilde{F}(V) := \sum_{j = 0}^n F[j] \otimes_{S_j} V^{\otimes j}F~(V):=∑j=0n​F[j]⊗Sj​​V⊗j. In fact this formula for the Schur functor F~\tilde{F}F~ makes sense for any 2-rig, taking VVV to be an arbitrary object in the 2-rig. In particular, it can be applied to V=L1⊕⋯⊕LnV = L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_nV=L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​ in A⊗n\mathsf{A}^{\otimes n}A⊗n.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:49):

The splitting principle we use concerns properties of the 2-rig map kS‾→A⊠n\overline{k\mathsf{S}} \to \mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes n}kS→A⊠n that takes FFF to F~(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)\tilde{F}(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n)F~(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​). In the form that we use it here, it states that the restriction of this 2-rig map to the subcategory of Schur objects or polynomial functors of degree at most nnn is essentially injective, i.e., if

F~(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)≅G~(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)\tilde{F}(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n) \cong \tilde{G}(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n)F~(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)≅G~(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)

for F,GF, GF,G of degree at most nnn, then F≅GF \cong GF≅G. (Actually we prove more: that this restricted functor is faithful and conservative as well. But the essential injectivity property just stated is the one that is really key.)

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:49):

We can play with this a bit. For example, we can calculate

Λj(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)\Lambda^j(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n)Λj(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)

(the Schur functor Λj\Lambda^jΛj is F~\tilde{F}F~ in the case where F=sgnjF = \mathrm{sgn}_jF=sgnj​, the sign representation of SjS_jSj​), by exploiting the exponential identity mentioned earlier:

Λj(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)≅⨁j1+…+jn=jΛj1(L1)⊗⋯⊗Λjn(Ln).\Lambda^j(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n) \cong \bigoplus_{j_1 + \ldots + j_n = j} \Lambda^{j_1}(L_1) \otimes \cdots \otimes \Lambda^{j_n}(L_n).Λj(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)≅⨁j1​+…+jn​=j​Λj1​(L1​)⊗⋯⊗Λjn​(Ln​).

For a line object LLL, Λp(L)=0\Lambda^p(L) = 0Λp(L)=0 for all p>1p > 1p>1, as is easily shown by induction (since Λp+1(r)\Lambda^{p+1}(r)Λp+1(r) is a retract of r⊗Λp(r)r \otimes \Lambda^p(r)r⊗Λp(r) in any 2-rig). Thus the only summands that survive on the right in the last display line are the ones where all the indices j1,…,jnj_1, \ldots, j_nj1​,…,jn​ are 000 or 111 (and add up to jjj). Thus

Λj(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)≅⨁1≤i1<…<ij≤nLi1⊗⋯⊗Lij.\Lambda^j(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n) \cong \bigoplus_{1 \leq i_1 < \ldots < i_j \leq n} L_{i_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes L_{i_j}.Λj(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)≅⨁1≤i1​<…<ij​≤n​Li1​​⊗⋯⊗Lij​​.

Letting xix_ixi​ denote the isomorphism class [Li][L_i][Li​], the Grothendieck ring of A⊠n\mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes n}A⊠n is isomorphic to the polynomial ring Z[x1,…,xn]\mathbb{Z}[x_1, \ldots, x_n]Z[x1​,…,xn​], and the isomorphism class of the coproduct on the right is

∑1≤i1<…<ij≤nxi1xi2⋯xij\sum_{1 \leq i_1 < \ldots < i_j \leq n} x_{i_1} x_{i_2} \cdots x_{i_j}∑1≤i1​<…<ij​≤n​xi1​​xi2​​⋯xij​​

which is precisely the jthj^{th}jth elementary symmetric polynomial ej(x1,…,xn)e_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n)ej​(x1​,…,xn​) as defined by the identity

∑j=0nej(x1,…,xn)tn=∏i=1n(1+xit).\sum_{j = 0}^n e_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n) t^n = \prod_{i=1}^n (1 + x_i t).∑j=0n​ej​(x1​,…,xn​)tn=∏i=1n​(1+xi​t).

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:50):

Similarly, the exponential identity for the symmetric powers yields

Sj(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)≅⨁j1+…+jn=jSj1(L1)⊗⋯⊗Sjn(Ln)S^j(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n) \cong \bigoplus_{j_1 + \ldots + j_n = j} S^{j_1}(L_1) \otimes \cdots \otimes S^{j_n}(L_n)Sj(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)≅⨁j1​+…+jn​=j​Sj1​(L1​)⊗⋯⊗Sjn​(Ln​)

and using the fact noted earlier that for line objects LLL we have Sn(L)≅L⊗nS^n(L) \cong L^{\otimes n}Sn(L)≅L⊗n, this may be rewritten as

Sj(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)≅⨁j1+…+jn=jL1⊗j1⊗⋯⊗Ln⊗jn.S^j(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n) \cong \bigoplus_{j_1 + \ldots + j_n = j} L_1^{\otimes j_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes L_n^{\otimes j_n}.Sj(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)≅⨁j1​+…+jn​=j​L1⊗j1​​⊗⋯⊗Ln⊗jn​​.

The isomorphism class of the expression on the right is

∑j1+…+jn=jx1j1⋯xnjn\sum_{j_1 + \ldots + j_n = j} x_1^{j_1} \cdots x_n^{j_n}∑j1​+…+jn​=j​x1j1​​⋯xnjn​​

which is precisely hj(x1,…,xn)h_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n)hj​(x1​,…,xn​), the jthj^{th}jth complete homogeneous polynomial in nnn variables, as defined by the identity

∑j=0∞hj(x1,…,xn)tn=∏i=1n11−xit.\sum_{j = 0}^\infty h_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n) t^n = \prod_{i=1}^n \frac1{1 - x_i t}.∑j=0∞​hj​(x1​,…,xn​)tn=∏i=1n​1−xi​t1​.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:51):

Letting Λn\Lambda_nΛn​ be the Grothendieck group of the category of Schur objects of degree at most nnn, the splitting principle implies that the induced map

Λn→Z[x1,…,xn],\Lambda_n \to \mathbb{Z}[x_1, \ldots, x_n],Λn​→Z[x1​,…,xn​],

taking [F][F][F] to [F~(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)][\tilde{F}(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n)][F~(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)], is an injection. Of course [F~(L1⊕⋯⊕Ln)][\tilde{F}(L_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus L_n)][F~(L1​⊕⋯⊕Ln​)] is manifestly invariant under permutations of the elements xi=[Li]x_i = [L_i]xi​=[Li​], so that elements in the image of this map are symmetric polynomials in the xix_ixi​ (of degree no more than nnn). Recall that every symmetric polynomial in variables x1,…,xnx_1, \ldots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ is uniquely a polynomial p(e1,…,en)p(e_1, \ldots, e_n)p(e1​,…,en​) in the elementary symmetric polynomials ej=ej(x1,…,xn)e_j = e_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n)ej​=ej​(x1​,…,xn​). Provided that the total degree of p(e1,…,en)p(e_1, \ldots, e_n)p(e1​,…,en​) is no more than nnn (where the degree of eje_jej​ is of course jjj), we have

p(λ1,…,λn)∈Λn.p(\lambda^1, \ldots, \lambda^n) \in \Lambda_n.p(λ1,…,λn)∈Λn​.

Since the map Λn→Z[x1,…,xn]\Lambda_n \to \mathbb{Z}[x_1, \ldots, x_n]Λn​→Z[x1​,…,xn​] carries λj\lambda^jλj to ej(x1,…,xn)e_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n)ej​(x1​,…,xn​), we deduce that every class [F]∈Λn[F] \in \Lambda_n[F]∈Λn​ is a polynomial p(λ1,…,λn)p(\lambda^1, \ldots, \lambda^n)p(λ1,…,λn) of total degree no more than nnn, which is already a nontrivial theorem. It says that every polynomial functor of degree less than or equal to nnn is isomorphic to a suitable coproduct of tensor powers of exterior power functors.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:52):

We are beginning to come full circle. Passing to suitable limits, explained in our paper, we can summarize one of our consequences of the splitting principle by the intuitive formula

1+λ1t+λ2t2+⋯=∏n=1∞(1+[Li]t)1 + \lambda^1 t + \lambda^2 t^2 + \cdots = \prod_{n=1}^\infty (1 + [L_i]t)1+λ1t+λ2t2+⋯=∏n=1∞​(1+[Li​]t)

so that we are splitting an "infinite polynomial" into linear factors, a la splitting extensions in the sense of Galois theory, and the coefficients λi\lambda^iλi are thereby manifestly identified with symmetric functions in the xi=[Li]x_i = [L_i]xi​=[Li​], which play a role similar to roots in the splitting extension.

Todd Trimble (Oct 18 2024 at 21:52):

Similarly, we may write

1+σ1t+σ2t2+⋯=∏n=1∞(1−[Li]t)−1.1 + \sigma^1 t + \sigma^2 t^2 + \cdots = \prod_{n=1}^\infty (1 - [L_i]t)^{-1}.1+σ1t+σ2t2+⋯=∏n=1∞​(1−[Li​]t)−1.

This goes at least some distance towards answers to some of John's questions at the top of this thread, although we still have some ways to go. I'm going to take a break for the moment.

Todd Trimble (Oct 19 2024 at 13:49):

I think what you wrote, p(t)=∏i=1n(t+ai)=∑i=0nei(a1,…,an)p(t) = \prod_{i=1}^n (t + a_i) = \sum_{i=0}^n e_i(a_1, \ldots, a_n)p(t)=∏i=1n​(t+ai​)=∑i=0n​ei​(a1​,…,an​), and what I wrote at 49 past the hour, ∑j=0nej(x1,…,xn)tj=∏i=1n(1+xit)\sum_{j=0}^n e_j(x_1, \ldots, x_n) t^j = \prod_{i=1}^n (1 + x_i t)∑j=0n​ej​(x1​,…,xn​)tj=∏i=1n​(1+xi​t), are basically the same thing. "My p(t)p(t)p(t)" is tnt^ntn times your p(1/t)p(1/t)p(1/t), is the way I would match things up.

As I've mentioned to you and Joe in private conversation, I very much have in mind that either way, Q(x1,…,xn)\mathbb{Q}(x_1, \ldots, x_n)Q(x1​,…,xn​) is a splitting field extension of its subfield Q(e1,…,en)\mathbb{Q}(e_1, \ldots, e_n)Q(e1​,…,en​), with Galois group SnS_nSn​. When the textbooks talk about unsolvability of the quintic and so on, that's really the formal framework of what they're discussing (maybe replace here Q\mathbb{Q}Q by any field). So we start with indeterminates e1,…,ene_1, \ldots, e_ne1​,…,en​ that have no special meaning attached to them, and pass to the splitting field of p(t)=tn+e1tn−1+⋯+enp(t) = t^n + e_1 t^{n-1} + \cdots + e_np(t)=tn+e1​tn−1+⋯+en​ (alternate those terms if you like) and basically wind up with Q(x1,…,xn)\mathbb{Q}(x_1, \ldots, x_n)Q(x1​,…,xn​) which is abstractly isomorphic to the original field, but which (now thinking geometrically) fibers over it differently, with fibers given by SnS_nSn​-torsors.

[I'll say again that I perceive a kind of unity between the various uses of the word "splitting" (splitting a polynomial, splitting into eigenspaces, splitting into line bundles, etc., even splitting field in the sense of representation theory, although I would need to recall the story of why I thought that's similar).]

But anyway, this fibering reminds me of configuration spaces, how nnn-tuples of distinct points in C\mathbb{C}C, say, fiber over nnn-element subsets of C\mathbb{C}C. Jim D. sometimes talks about this sort of thing, too.

In my write-up here, I'm thinking of Λ\LambdaΛ as a ring filtered by the Λn\Lambda_nΛn​, but one can argue that really what we should be thinking of is that the quotient ring Λ/(λn+1)\Lambda/(\lambda^{n+1})Λ/(λn+1) is Z[e1,…,en]\mathbb{Z}[e_1, \ldots, e_n]Z[e1​,…,en​]. This would correspond to a lambda-ring generated by Young diagrams with nnn rows or fewer, whereas the filtration component Λn\Lambda_nΛn​ is not a ring, and corresponds to Young diagrams with nnn boxes or fewer.

We didn't quite get to a full explanation of the Λ/(λn+1)\Lambda/(\lambda^{n+1})Λ/(λn+1) picture in our paper, which we certainly hold (without proving this) to be the Grothendieck ring of the 2-rig of algebraic representations of the multiplicative monoid hom⁡(V,V)\hom(V, V)hom(V,V) where VVV is an nnn-dimensional vector space. Same as the monoid MnM_nMn​ of n×nn \times nn×n matrices. We denote this 2-rig of algebraic representations as

Rep(Mn)\mathsf{Rep}(M_n)Rep(Mn​)

and the "splitting principle pretense" of acting as if matrices can be diagonalized, split into 1-dimensional eigenspaces, is formalized by considering the pullback functor

Rep(Mn)→Rep(kn)\mathsf{Rep}(M_n) \to \mathsf{Rep}(k^n)Rep(Mn​)→Rep(kn)

where knk^nkn is the multiplicative submonoid of diagonal matrices, and showing that this pullback functor satisfies our trio of conditions: faithful, conservative, and essentially injective. (For the readers out there, this is one of our main results.) We also observe that Rep(kn)\mathsf{Rep}(k^n)Rep(kn) is equivalent to A⊠n\mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes n}A⊠n, the walking 2-rig on nnn line objects.

Anyway, what I am leading up to here is that maybe in some ways it's better to think of kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS not as a colimit or union of its filtered pieces kS≤n‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}_{\leq n}}kS≤n​​, as we do in the paper, but as a limit of 2-rig quotients kS‾/(Λn+1)\overline{k\mathsf{S}}/(\Lambda^{n+1})kS/(Λn+1). Not a limit in a "naive" 2-rig sense, but in a graded 2-rig sense. This is analogous to how we typically treat the cohomology algebra H∗(BU)H^\ast(BU)H∗(BU): not as an inverse limit of H∗(BU(n))≅Z[e1,…,en]H^\ast(BU(n)) \cong \mathbb{Z}[e_1, \ldots, e_n]H∗(BU(n))≅Z[e1​,…,en​] in the category of rings (now interpreting the eie_iei​ as Chern classes!), but as an inverse limit in the category of graded rings, leading to the polynomial algebra Λ=Z[e1,e2,…]\Lambda = \mathbb{Z}[e_1, e_2, \ldots]Λ=Z[e1​,e2​,…] in infinitely many variables.

I'm thinking that this inverse limit perspective on Λ\LambdaΛ, placing it in the same neighborhood as how we treat A⊠∞\mathsf{A}^{\boxtimes \infty}A⊠∞ as an inverse limit in a graded sense, might lead to a more harmonious picture of what is going on at the level of Galois groups. For example, it might clarify whether we are thinking of this S∞S_\inftyS∞​ as the full permutation group, or just the union of the SnS_nSn​ (I'm thinking the former is more appropriate).

Q[x1,…,xn]→Q[x1,…,xn,xn+1] \mathbb{Q}[x_1, \dots, x_n] \to \mathbb{Q}[x_1, \dots, x_n, x_{n+1}] Q[x1​,…,xn​]→Q[x1​,…,xn​,xn+1​]
